bibl.title: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, May 4, 1925

div1.p: Scannell discusses the mud puddle breeding of mosquitoes in Africa. He is confident that the yellow fever work in Africa will succeed.

div1.head: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, May 4, 1925
div1.p:
I have just finished reading a
reprint of yours regarding the
possibility of mud puddle breeding
in Africa of the Aedes aegypti
and was much interested but
it does not appear to me to
be a cause for worry, for as
you well know, field men
always find a way out- In
Brazil, where the problems were
many, the directors had little
difficulty in overcoming any new
hazard that presented-

Given a certain amount of
ability and the determination to
win I am satisfied a man
will have little difficulty in
circummenting the Aedes Aegypti
in any field, at any time.
However it will be interesting to
learn whether or no the Aedes
in Africa does actually breed in
numbers in mud puddles and
swamps.

Dr. White has a well trained
organization in Brazil and
with the same outfit in Africa
the Board should soon be
able to clean up any of the
areas involved-

I am here for a little change
after over two years service without
a vacation. Am getting some new
glasses and having my teeth fixed
up.

I trust this finds you improved
and able to get out - up here
the weather is warm and spring
like.
Please commend me to Miss Carter.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, E. J. Scannell. Dr. H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
